text:
East River--River Scenes: Early ships and shipping on the river below the Brooklyn Bridge. South Street is the marginal Manhattan thoroughfare from which the various anchorages project.

Early 1900's
Views 1,2

Thomas W. Kennedy Collection
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Association
Grand Central Terminal
title: East River scenes.

title: East River scenes.

text:
(1)
East River Scenes: Water front activity off South Street near the financial district of lower Manhattan. This photo appeared in Camera Work of 1908.

1908.

A. L. Cobwin.

(2)
The same locale at a later date. In the foreground appears a river schooner with a spread canvas.

Summer 1924.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River scenes.

title: East River scenes.

folder: Piers 16-17 - Manhattan - South Street - [City Bank-Farmers Trust Company ; Farmer's Loan and Trust Company.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Piers 16 and 17 East River, east side of South Street. Pier 17 in the foreground. The shed covering pier 16 appears beyond the ships March 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle. March 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, showing the 120 Wall Street and the City Bank and Farmers Trust Co, Buildings. September 23, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Piers 16-17 - Manhattan - South Street - [City Bank-Farmers Trust Company ; Farmer's Loan and Trust Company.]

folder: Piers 16-17 - [Unloading boats for Fulton fish market.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Piers 17 and 16, East River, east side of South Street. The view shows boats unloading for the Fulton Fish Market.

May 2, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a closer view.

May 2, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Piers 16-17 - [Unloading boats for Fulton fish market.]

text:
East River: Off South Street; habitat of man and cargo. A quiet moment on New York's, otherwise busy, waterway. 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.
title: East River scenes.
